I'll add an additional positive testimonial for clover--we found them 
easy to integrate, and very helpful customer service.  However, we also 
found that, in general, it helped us more in finding dead code than in 
identifying new opportunities to test.

    David Saff

Kent Beck wrote:

> Thomas,
>
> I don't think this coverage is off-topic at all, since the coverage 
> testers
> I've tried all use JUnit tests to initiate execution of the code.
>
> As it happens, Erich and I measured the coverage of our tests in JUnit 4
> today. We used Coverlipse first. I liked the user interface (you initiate
> coverage measurement with a new kind of launch configuration), but the
> results weren't accurate. We set breakpoints on lines that the tool 
> claimed
> weren't covered and execution stopped there. We also tried Clover, 
> which has
> a slightly less natural interface (you set an "enable Clover" flag on the
> project properties). The results, however, seemed much more accurate.
>
> The result of our testing was that we found two methods out of JUnit 4 
> that
> we felt needed tests. Our overall coverage is 68%, and it seems like it
> would be easy to get it up to 80%. However, the only functional code that
> really needed more tests were those two methods.
>
> Sincerely yours,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
